instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_E85</SIGNAL> Cycling
threads.message: This board had a short on PP3V33R3V0_AON. I replaced <CHIP>U4700</CHIP> and it worked fine for a couple days. The battery was on the low end - around 78% capacity and it was changing a fair amount going anywhere from 73% up to 81% as it charged and drained. I drained it all the way down and then after plugging in the power adapter it would just chime every few second randomly as if it was losing and then regaining connection to the adapter. After pulling the board I measured that <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_E85</SIGNAL> is cycling up and down. I can't find any shorts , PP3V33R3V0_AON is not shorted and am not finding any components heating up. Any idea what might have failed here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_E85</SIGNAL> Cycling
threads.message:
The board doesn't work without battery now, like before?
Which are the limit flcutations for F7140 and L7095 now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_E85</SIGNAL> Cycling
threads.message:
The battery was drained completely and my other one is also drained. It might actually work on battery though.

About .010V is the highest L7095 gets. F7140 stays steady at .010V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_E85</SIGNAL> Cycling
threads.message:
So it doesn't work on charger only now.
Check resistance to ground on the ponits above mentioned; also check on <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR>.
What is the voltage on F7140 if connected only battery?

Check if <TRANSISTOR>Q7110</TRANSISTOR>/20 are both OK.
